title: When starting a band, why is it so hard to find a good bass player? - Quora

response.answer_text: As everyone else has mentioned, most people initially prefer to play guitar. That’s largely because there are many more “superstar” guitarists than bassists. Sure there are excellent very well known bassists, but how many of those bassists (especially one’s who didn’t start out as guitarists) are the actual leader of their band? Thinking about it, even Paul McCartney of The Beatles and Jack Bruce of Cream, both having a strong leadership role, were still not the exclusive leaders of their bands. The only one I can think of is Phil Lynott of Thin Lizzie. Still, how does he rank compared to Jimi Hendrix, Eric Clapton, Jimmy Page, or Stevie Ray Vaugh? Certainly a “star”, but not really a “superstar” of that high of a magnitude. A mere bass player. Ho-hum. Not a “Guitar God”. It’s perception. Sure you can put up ads, and audition dozens of bass players, ranging from awful to mediocre… And you may get really, really lucky and find a truly great bassist… But it’s like playing the lottery. Better odds of getting hit by lightning. My advice… Go hang around music stores. A lot. There, you can audition bassists without them even realizing it! No having to say “Um… sorry, you’re not exactly the bassist we’re looking for…” …After the poor guy took the effort to carry his heavy bass rig down the narrow stairs into your practice space… No having to see the totally disappointed look on their hopeful face and feeling guilted into letting them join your band… Only to have to toss them out on their ear later , when they just can’t seem to learn the intricate and difficultly timed parts of your songs. None of that “drama”… Just “Hey that guy in the corner trying out amps can really play excellently!” Let’s ask him! - Even if they’re already solidly in a band, and decline to “audition your band”, here’s a lesser known tip… Most really good bassists also know or at least know of other really good bassists who are currently looking for a band! Alternately, even if they don’t, maybe ask them to teach you how to play bass like a actual bassist. Like they do. Most bassists are generally pretty easy going and friendly. And willing to help out other bassists and musicians. Willing to show some great techniques. Playing bass requires most of the same knowledge of the neck… And music theory, timing, etc. as for guitar. And often more music theory. Sure guitarists know plenty of scales, but ask one to play the “third” note of a key, or the “fifth”, and nine out of ten will just blink at you with glassy eyes. Hum it and they’re there. (Once they’ve poked around to find it.) Where bassists mostly differ, is usually in their willingness to take the back seat, out of the limelight. A good guitarist who is willing to give up “hot-dogging” in order to support their band can become a better bassist than some guy who only took bass up “because it had only four strings and looked easier”. Horrible bass players started out with that thinking. Which is why they suck, and always will. The fact is, it’s not easier… …At least if you’re really doing a really great job at it. Can’t find a great bassist? Become a great bassist. Then you’ll be the one in demand if your band ever splits up. And, even if you later decide that bass playing isn’t for you, you’ll have a unique perspective of what a great bassist really does, and how music actually fits together to be great. It worked out splendidly for Jimmy Page. It can work out great for you too. My story… A friend and I decided to learn guitar together. Once we both got to a certain point, we decided to form a band. Well someone had to play bass. He got a cheap bass and played bass for a short while. But, he had another friend who was a great guitarist, that started teaching him all the amazing things we couldn’t ever figure out on our own. Then my buddy bought himself a brand new Gibson SG. Meanwhile I was still “plinking” on a really horrible Sears and Roebuck piece of garbage. So I was effectively forced into playing bass, and just a little bit disgruntled at the time. But he was (and still is) a great friend, so I got over it pretty quickly. Fortunately, I realized it wasn’t about me, it was about “the band”. Once I started to figure out and master basslines by Jack Bruce, John Paul Jones, Jack Casady and lots of other great bassists, I realized he actually did me a huge, huge favor. Playing bass was both challenging and fun. And there is nothing like the feeling you get playing bass, standing next to the bass amp, cranked way up! It’s an indescribable feeling of power. Those low bass notes rattle your bones, not just your ears. It’s really the bass that drives the power of music, not so much the guitar as I had once thought. While I never got to be the great lead guitarist he became, I became an excellent bassist, and in many ways a much, much better guitarist for it. It gave me the opportunity to learn and really understand all the different parts required to make music great and just how they all fit together. What the role of the bassist really is. And trust me, it’s not just holding down “The Groove”. Sure that is really important, but bass can be very melodic too. And, there are things you can play that make the guitar actually sound more complex than it really is. For instance if you play a descending line and take it down an interval each go-around while the guitar just repeats the initial descending phrase, it’s magical. And there you are, playing… Grinning like a little kid inside, because you’re the only one who knows that secret. Too cool! Try it… Play bass. You have nothing whatsoever to lose, and a lot to gain. (EDIT) Here’s tablature for an easy standard Bass lick to get you going:

“Hey mom, can I take bass lessons?” said nobody ever. Or hardly ever. Guitar? Check. Drums? Check. Keyboards? Yup. Bass? “You wanna be a bass player?” Odds are your bass player is going to be a converted guitarist. Why? Because bands are expected to have bass players. Somebody’s gotta do it. And most mediocre guitar players can usually (and quickly) be turned into reasonably mediocre bass players. The bass, after all, isn’t much more than the third, fourth, fifth and sixth strings of the guitar - tuned one octave down with its notes played on a nearly identical fret board. All of those notes can be found roughly in the same place they are on the guitar. As a result, becoming an adequate bass player isn’t all that tough. Becoming a good bass player is another story. It takes work. And, to be honest, it ain’t all that much fun. A good bass player understands the instrument’s role. And the theory behind playing the thing. The bass drives the beat. It creates counterpoint. And, of course, it fills in the bottom end. A good bass player develops an ear for the instrument that goes beyond those tired three chord step runs. A good bass player intuitively knows what notes go, or can go, where … and why. And how a little creativity can take a song in an entirely different and distinctive direction. The good ones, the truly good ones, are a rarity. They’re people who’ve committed to the instrument as an instrument - rather than a flirtation or a temporary sideline brought about by necessity. And they work at it. With little or no expectation of recognition for the contribution they and that instrument are making to the sound. The bass is music’s witness protection program. Nobody notices you’re there - until you’re not. Advice: Get good. No bass player? Rent one from the Internet by investing a few bucks for a custom bass backing track that can be used to record a demo. Post it to a site like Bandmix. State what you’re looking for in a bass player. If your demo tracks are good, the bass players - the real bass players - will seek you out.

This may have already been stated in the other answers but I make it a point never to look at the other answers before I leave an answer. So I apologize in advance for any possible redundancies that I may be guilty of. My answer to your question is more of an observation about guitar players. Many guitar players, and I mean a whole lot of them, think that just because they can fret a note on a bass guitar that that means they can play the bass, and technically that’s true, but that by no means makes that guitar player a bassist. Not by any stretch of the imagination. Not that being a guitar player and a bassist are mutually exclusive of each other. There are many examples of it, for instance, Paul Macartney and Stephen Stills come to mind as does Mike Rutheford. But playing the bass is a whole different headspace than playing the guitar and most guitar players really don’t share that headspace. And if it doesn’t come naturally you really have to make a concerted effort to get yourself there. Something that few guitar players are able to pull off. Or maybe just unwilling, but it all boils down to the same thing. I am a guitar player who plays the bass on all the songs I write and record but by no means do I consider myself a bassist. The same goes for Drums and keyboards. I take on those roles by default as I am alone when I write and record music. I have included here a song I wrote in which I attempted to get that 60s Motown vibe that I really love. I don’t know that I succeeded but my point is that I really had to disconnect myself from my guitar player side to find an appropriate bass part, which in turn helped me find an appropriate drum part. It goes without saying that I am no James Jamerson, but then again, who really is. James is up there amongst the all time greats for good reason. So I guess to answer your question I would just have to say it’s because a good bass player is a rare animal to find. So if you are lucky enough to come across one, don’t be a dick to him or her. Because in reality, it is the presence of bass that actually makes the sound of the guitar sound so good and should be greatly appreciated and held up high. The Note

Bass is hard because of the multiple tasks of rhythm, root and counterpoint. In the Baroque Era, music was often written for lead and “continuo”. The continuo could be notated by a bass note or chord, and was interpreted by variable ensemble, most often some combination of a theorbos, harpsichord and bass viols. We have reduced this three to five person section to a single bass, aided by the replacement of a percussion section by a trap set. The Viol player had to be well versed in the forms, styles, scales and conventions of the era - and when I say scales, they had to move the frets for the differing scales of Italy, France, Germany and England, none of which were equal divisions. Southern music tended to favor thirds and Northern music fifths, but there were also regional variants. It is not so different today - Blues, Jazz and Wold music use bent notes and have historical patterns in modes, rhythm and accent feel so deep they take years to learn and are best as native languages, heard from birth. The stylistic patterns have to be so deeply entrained they are instinctive, because all performances should be a jam offering something fresh and relevant to the moment. The bassist also has to understand everything else that is going on. The relationship of bass to vocals is critical. Listen to John McVie, John S. Denman, Tony Levin, Pino Palladino, Paul McCartney, Carole Kaye, Chuck Rainey, Nathan East, or the original, Ray Brown. He was so good he married Ella! Duck Dunn at Stax, James Jamerson and Bob Babbitt at Motown - the bass makes it happen. The bass sets the beat, and expresses it ahead or behind a precise amount. This timing is way below millisecond divisions into microseconds, and the more remarkable because bass instruments (especially bass SPEAKERS) have millisecond delays dependent on the note. The bassist has to hold the key and tie the harmonic progression together vertically and horizontally with leading tones, foreshadowing and echoes - and come back to the root one every time depending on the genre. The proper bass attitude is like the musical mother of the band, making sure everybody sticks together and gets what they need. For all of this the bass is often considered a detail because much of the best bass is invisible, especially in blues and rock like Tommy Shannon, Harvey Brooks, Bill Wyman or Dee Anthony. Bass is only allowed to step out in instrumental music and even then it usually can’t “get busy”, it’s more “down to business” on the low end. With all these skills, practice, history, and psyche including the ability to carry on repetitive figures with little recognition, it is not surprising that good ones are rare.

We’re a rare sort. Here I speak of actual bassists, not guitarists who sit in on bass occasionally. Most people want to be out front. In rock, that means lead guitar and vocals. The bass—in most, but not all, bands—plays a supporting role. We make the rest of you sound better. We lock in with the drums to create the rhythm that moves the audience. We anchor the harmony so you can take your leads with confidence. We step out once in a while, too. But it’s not the main thing, for us. So, to be a good bassist, you need a good sense of time, a good sense of harmony, and a self-effacing, supportive disposition. These are exceedingly rare qualities. Someone has already said that some bassists are guys who wanted to be guitarists but couldn’t manage it—an old saw that I tire of hearing, though there’s some truth to it. Here’s an observation in the opposite direction, from the point-of-view of a bassist. It’s been my experience that good bassists are often the smart guys in the band. As such, they can find something else to do with their time. They’re likely to have many interests. They’re likely to be gainfully employed. Can you say the same for most guitarists you’ve met? I can’t. Guitar is the most popular instrument in the world. Bass probably isn’t in the top 50. It’s a tuba, basically. It’s a really sexy tuba. I love it. I think it’s the coolest instrument in the history of instruments. But most people don’t share my love of it. They’d rather be singers, or guitarists, or drummers. We’re the few and the proud. We’re an odd brotherhood of under-appreciated craftsmen who make things click, even though most people never realize it.

As several others have said, bass isn't a glamorous instrument. Most young, aspiring musicians want to be in the spotlight; they want to step up and lay down that killer guitar solo in front of hundreds/thousands of screaming, adoring fans. That's something that most bass players don't get to do. Fact is, most of them don't want to — which should tell you right there that bass players usually have a different mindset. The best ones are all about the music; they understand how essential the bass is to the music. That understanding, however, leads many bassists to an overinflated sense of their own value and makes them impossible to work with. In my experience, the hard part isn't finding a bass player, it's finding a really GOOD bass player who digs the genre I've chosen for my project, who isn't already committed to a project (or is overcommitted to several other projects), and who isn't a flake, narcissist, megalomaniac, primal donna, addict/alcoholic, or drama queen. I have ONE rule in my bands- NO DRAMA - and most of the talented bassists in my area seem to be unable to live with that. The biggest reason, it seems to me, that finding a good bassist is so hard, comes down to geography. Chances are, you wouldn't have a problem if you were in LA, Seattle, Chicago, Miami, or NYC. If you're in a major metropolitan area and you still can't find a bass player, you might need to look inward.

Because there’s hardly anyone claiming to be a “bass player”. Instead, you’ll be choosing from among the league of mediocre guitar players who will concede and play bass just to get in a band. As a former punk rock vocalist who’s way too old to be a frontman, I am considering taking up the bass, which is the only rock & roll instrument I’ve ever had any interest in learning. I want to start with it too, and not come around to it from the guitar. I have always sung (and written) lyrics based on what the rhythm section was doing, to some degree ignoring the guitar parts as other free-standing outfront instrumentals, paying just enough attention to stay in key (or out, depending). The bass is what you move too, and is often providing a melody that you don’t recognize unless it’s isolated or removed. The latter is what I find so difficult to enjoy in all of the two-piece bands that have proliferated in recent years; especially under the umbrella of Metal. It is almost always a guitarist & drummer, one or both doing vocals if there are any. Not only are they generally quite boring to look at playing live, I have yet to hear one that I don’t find lacking sonically as well. No amount of down-tuning and/or effects pedals on a guitar can make up for the visceral waves and pulses that a bass line can inject into any musical genre, and it most certainly can’t replace the thunderous, martial, staccato punch that is fundamentally required for Metal. A double-kick bass drum comes close, but no cigar.

I’ve looked at your profile, but it’s blank, so I’m firing off some ideas off the top of my head. Factors affecting this might be: Where you liveYour ageThe kind of music you playYour attitude!Playing of any instrument is helped by lessons from local teachers and role modelling of good players in local bands. Perhaps there is not enough of a bass community in your area. Bass is not so hard to play, but if you’re young you might overlook it in favour of guitar because it seems more glamorous. Many pro bass players have taken up the instrument because there were enough guitarists in the band already! They usually realise how enjoyable playing bass is, as well as how much more marketable than guitar, and have no regrets. Genre can make a lot of difference. Various metal sub-genres can be ferociously demanding, in terms of both stamina and tricky time signatures. Ditto with things like fusion. What kind of music do you play? Is it a case of not being able to find someone who has both the skill level required and a desire to play that kind of music? I have to raise the question of what kind of band leader you are - if you are - as bands work well when there is either clear leadership from someone with a vision, or a genuine collective spirit. In both cases clear communication is required and a positive, supportive attitude. Better to have a bassist who is a good fit in personal terms and who could develop the skill level. What are your requirements of your bass player? If you’re young and just starting out, I don’t believe it has to be an issue of gear. There are lots of budget basses around that are perfectly good for basic gigging, ditto with backline. Some pro bassists go straight into the PA through something like a Sansamp Bass Driver DI, so they might not even need an amp.

Hmmmm. You know I’ve wondered this too. I was in a band in high school and bass was the last position we got ironed out. And it took like, months. One reason could be that bassists often play other instruments. I know several bass players who are in reality, multi-instrumentalists, but make bass their main instrument because it’s the only rock instrument that doesn’t really need to stand out, and if you can play many instruments, maybe you haven’t focused hugely on just one. Additionally, these bassists might already be in a band as either the bassist, keyboardist, horn player, guitarist, singer, you name it. Since, as you mentioned, good bassists are at a premium, they tend to get snatched up quick, leaving only the beginners or scrubs. Another reason is good bass players tend to take music, and musical projects that they enter into, really seriously, so they’re very selective. My former band’s bassist only likes to play with a handful of people. A band a few of my friends had broke up because-you guessed it- the bassist left, unsatisfied. Thirdly, most bassists I know are very introverted. They might just be shy about their skills or playing with/for people they don’t know. I feel like guitarists, drummers, and singers are more likely to flaunt themselves. They’re out there!

The obvious reason is that there are fewer bass players than players of other instruments, but I suppose you are asking why? In short, outside of jazz, bass is often an afterthought in music. I’ve heard people claim that certain songs don’t even have a bass part in it, where to me it’s clear as day. Many bass parts in contemporary popular and rock music are quite simple to play, and sometimes low in the mix- it’s not that part of the music that people sit up and pay attention to. The parts that people do hear easily and pay attention to are the singer and lead guitar player, which is why it’s quite easy to find singers and guitar players (or even singing guitar players). It would be fairly easy for most rock fans to name a dozen or more popular guitar players in rock history (JimmyPageKeithRichardsJoeSatrianiEddieVanHalenTedNugentPeteTownshendSlashJimiHendrixPeterFramptonJeffBuckleyBobDylanNealSchon … <breath>), but can anyone do the same for bass players? Maybe I could, because I enjoy nerding out like that, but most casual music fans probably don’t even know who James Jamerson or Jaco Pastorious are. So you’re looking for someone who deliberately picked up an instrument that most people don’t care that much about and are adept at it. Generally, those that are decent have found a project already.

There are plenty of so-called musicians out there, including bass players, but the bass player is so fundamental to both the rhythmic and harmonic integrity of pretty much any type of band, that mediocre simply doesn’t cut it. Fundamental is related to the same root as foundation. You can build a crappy house on a good foundation and it will not fall down, but you can’t do the reverse. If your bass player isn’t performing his function adequately you will know it because the overall sound of your band will suck. Even decent musicians will not sound good with a bad bass player. No one wants anything except a good bass player, whereas you can put up with a mediocre guitar player (and all too often he’s the band leader anyway.) The other thing about bass players is that they play a line based on the roots of the chord charts and so they can play with lots of different bands. Because of that, good bass players are in high demand. They can pick and choose who they want to play with. My bass player, for example, hates playing with blues combos because it bores him to tears. So make sure that your band is fully committed, isn’t full of prima donnas and jerks, is organized and easy to work with, and offers some fun and interesting music to your prospective good bass player, or she’ll find someone better than you to gig with.

I have found many bass players are just guitarists with a bass. This often changes the function and sound of the bass(Chris Squire from Yes and very few others are exceptions to this rule). I have also found that so many people pick up the bass because it’s “easier to learn than guitar. This couldn’t be further from the truth. In spite of the fact that bassists do not usually play full chords like a 6 string player they must know the make up of each chord in order to create effective bass lines. Playing the root note on every song is usually not effective playing for an entire set at a gig. Of course it’s needed sometimes, but a bass player can bring excitement to a group by changing the note they play(for example, if the guitar is playing an F triad and I play an A or C it gives the chord a new feel) The other thing that makes GOOD bass players hard to find is the fact that many young players try to play the instrument like one long solo. Yes, we can be busy, but if a bassist doesn’t establish the groove a song dies. My idol John Entwistle was a very busy player, but he always played what the song called for. Listen to his playing with Moon and compare it to his playing with Kenny Jones. Very different, but equally effective. I love being a bass player!!! I hope this helps.

Supply and demand. There aren’t very many good bass players. Once you get known as a good bass player, you very quickly have offers of more work than you can actually do. So you get picky about what you take. What would you do, if you get an offer from two really good bands and one not quite so good, and you only have enough time to play for two? Yep, the not quite so good band has no bass player. Secondly, one of the reasons there seem to be fewer good bass players than there actually are is simple: have you looked at the prices of good bass gear? Yeah, your guitarist probably has equipment much further up the quality ladder than your bass player, unless somehow your bass player spent four times as much money. And there’s a bigger difference between a cheap crappy bass amp and a good one than there is with guitar gear. Double bass is even worse. You can buy a decent playable electric guitar and an amp for the price of a set of good double bass strings. Not kidding, last set I bought was $650… fortunately, they last for years.

James answer this perfectly : James Martin's answer to When starting a band, why is it so hard to find a good bass player? . But to look at it from different perspective, it is hard to find a bass player that fits the band. Just like a marriage, finding a right member could make or break the band. Of course, good and well seasoned bass player will definitely bring something new to the table, possibly elevate the band even more. But there is that one guy somewhere, that really belongs to a band. One time I got asked to join my friend’s band practice session. We played and we played, but it’s just didn’t feel right, we did not gel very well. Something was off and awkward. Then I listen to some of the song with their previous bass player. I surprised and really enjoy his basslines and that fits the song perfectly. While when I get together with my church pals and try to practice and arrange a song, boom. We got couple hours and we have bunch of finished song. It is about finding people with the same wavelength as yours. And if you do, don’t let them go.

Interesting. I’ve played bass for over forty years and I had to retire in the 80’s because I couldn’t find work. I’d show up to an audition, jam a little, maybe learn one or two of their songs—if they were playing originals and not copy—they’d nod, say “Thanks, we’ll let you know,” and I’d never near from them. I put a band together with a session guitarist in 1984 because I’d answered eight ads from other bands and nobody called me back. T’was a good group—but it flamed out under some really weird circumstances. I reckon I’ve played darned near every genre, from jazz to pop. Southern rock. Funk. Punk. Reggae. Top Forty. Old standards. I read and I can manuscript, so learning new tunes was never a problem for me. At jam sessions, I’d get compliments, but the best compliment is employment. I always had good gear, transportation, and a willingness to work with a-holes. I can work with Attila the Hun if he plays his parts right. In fact, I think I did for about six months but he was a heavy substance abuser like a lot of barbarian lead players. About a decade ago, I changed a few things and made my employability even less possible. (See picture) If it hadn’t been for my godson—offspring of the drummer and lead singer/guitarist in my first working pro band—I’d probably never play with anyone again. But we had a nice little band called Puppetshow (any Spinal Tap fans out there?) that played a mashup of copy and originals. We had fun, but I’ve pretty much quit playing professionally. I fiddle with recording, mess about on guitar, but don’t play bass much, even though I still have my Rick and a compact little Ampeg (BA115) that kicks ass for anything but a big stage. Instead, I’m a writing instructor in a city that seems pretty liberal, but hasn’t responded much to my musical overtures. Such is life.

My son is a professional bassist with a degree in jazz performance from a very good Conservatorium. The answer to your question has multiple facets - People like him are very rare. He has never wanted to be a guitarist, but as soon as he picked up a bass he fell in love with it.Bass is a VERY hard instrument to learn PROPERLY. Especially double bass. Mistakes in intonation and timing are obvious. It takes a very high degree of skill to do it properly, much more so than guitar which can cover up a multitude of sins.As a result of the above factors, he is run off his feet. He gets offers every week to join people’s projects. He turns about 95% of them down. If you want him to play with you, you must be earning good money playing interesting, improvisational music. Also, you must display a completely professional attitude and be easy to get along with. (There is a LOT that I could say about that) Otherwise, no go. He has 1 fun project (a metal band), but the others are working bands playing advanced prog or jazz.I hope that this helps to answer your question. P.S. With regard to the professional attitude bit. He has been known to walk out of rehearsals for new projects after 1/2 hr when it has become obvious that he is the only one who really knows his parts. It happens more than you might think.

Bands are funny. Too many tone deaf singers. Too many lead guitarists who don't know how to tune the instrument. Too many kids thinking "loud" shredding is better. Even Yngwie Malmsteen got annoying at times. Too much is too much. Bass is not a grandstanding instrument. It adds structure, foundation and rhythm. Not a lot of young players are interested in that. They watch too much TV and crap. Bass is always aware of everything going on musically between melody and drums. The best bass players are usually already at least decent guitarists who possesss a healthy understanding of band dynamics. You can be a weak guitarist and get away with bass but one still has to understand the responsibilities of band dynamics or else they'll create a musical mud pit. Most good bassists are down to earth knowledgeable musicians. How many bands have had bassists bounce around from their drama, fallout and a prima-donna attitude?

Imagine you're a kid and you want to learn to play music and maybe even sing, too. So you decide on an instrument that you can play actual songs with, not parts, songs. And even sing along. So you start with a guitar or a piano.  Guitars are portable, pianos not so much. As your musicianship grows, you decide to take on another instrument and learn more theory and styles and parts. That might lead you to taking up bass, or maybe harmonica, mandolin, banjo, lap steel, pedal steel, organ(not so portable), flute, percussion, etc.  I keep coming back to the portability issue. Basses are either double bass, a fairly large instrument, or electric, requiring rather large amplifiers to lug around and set up.So more than half start out on guitar, then maybe less than 10% of those take up bass so now your down to say 5% of musicians playing bass. Most performing bands have 4 people, more or less. So those 5% of musicians are asked to fill 25% of the positions in a band. Not enough bass players to go around.

A true bassist is not a burned out guitarist, or a guitar player that got delegated to Bass duties. The reason that good Bass players are hard to find is that the bass role typically is SEEN as a supporting role, and who wants to be subservient? The truth though is that without that low end ,whether felt or heard, the song being played will lack depth and a certain aspect of emotion. Just as in life, you cannot really have those “high” moments if you don't understand the profundity of those “low”. Truly dedicated Bassist are hard to find because sometimes either the person playing bass by default, or the musicians looking for “ a bass player" don't fully understand or realize the emotional impact that a bassist can offer to a band, or song.

It is easy to get basic bass tones out, easy to produce lots of volume (just turn the knob), and the pitch is hard to hear down low, so you don’t have to be that accurate to sound “OK.” Of course, it’s sounding really good that you’re after. And with a zillion wannabe bass players out there who think that volume = goodness = something very close to but not quite sex, you have to hear a lot of no-go’s before finding the good one. I trained a new bass player from scratch (I don’t play, just showed him where his fingers should go for the notes - made a chart). I should say, sort of trained, because while he was very willing to learn, the first week, and so many people complimented him, he was unteachable after that. I’m not sure if I’ve nailed down “why”, which is your question; but perhaps a little of that Why comes out in my meandering answer!

Because the bar for guitar players has been lowered so much by manufacturers in conjunction with the pyramid scheme that is the music industry. So everyone thinks they can be a guitar player. The bar for bass players now is even lower because: A) People don’t notice the bass because of the tinny, small speakered devices music is often listened to on now, so you have a general stereotype of it being inaudible or not mattering. B) Ego. If you actually put a little effort into learning something, bass can be pretty fun. If less people’s greed and egos compelled them to front their own project, we’d have fewer, but musically stronger bands, and maybe not such a disparity in importance placed on the various members of a guitar/rock/pop based band. :-)

First off never settle for a guitar player settling for bass. It never fails to amaze me. The arrogance that it's a simple instrument to play. The answer is true bassists are not abundant. It is a calling not a choice settled on because your a guitar flunky. A real bassist understands the role of holding down the bottom of the pocket, the rythm section, overall dynamics of a song and groove. All of this often inspires learning as much as possible about the nature sound & frequency, composition & arrangement. It is the love of the instrument that fuels all of this thirst for this knowledge. Now if you come across someone starting out all they have to know is they love the bass. The rest of their journey will come. If they have basic skill just be happy because they will explode with talent given a chance and some confidence.

I've been lucky enough to have never had that problem. My partner is a bass player and singer. When she found doing both too distracting we brought in bass players and have worked with some great ones. On the other other hand we always had trouble finding good drummers. It can be hard to find either because often they want more of a lead role than is actually required. Too many lead bass players and lead drummers out there! Good bass players and drummers understand that their role is to underpin the music - to be the engine. Sadly players like this are rare and so are in high demand. That alone makes them hard to find. Often they are in several bands already.

From my own band experiences, bass players tended to fall into one of two categories: someone who didn’t play all that well, and a guitarist relegated to bass duties because we already had a guitarist (but the guy playing bass wanted to step into that role). For me, the frustrated guitar players made the best bassists, because they had that New Order/The Jam lead/rhythm bass technique. Lots of melody, lots of creativity, more unique than just holding down the groove. This isn’t to say that holding down the groove isn’t important - it is. But I always like the sound of a ‘lead’ bass. The big problem with lead bass players is, they don’t keep time as well as someone holding down a groove. They miss their cues more often. They screw up more often. They don’t tend to re-learn holding down a groove.

I don’t have a solid answer for this. What I have always run into were these things when auditioning for bands in the past and I am a bass player. The lead guitarist was on a major ego trip and the bass player is his opinion was only there to fill in the bottom end of the sound, the drummers were usually cool if not great. And then there are the folks who really want to play guitar but as they put it will settle to playing bass if they can get into a band. I feel that good bass players are hard to find due to the fact not many folks really want to play bass as their main instrument. Myself I have a passion to playing bass, would rather play bass that keyboards, guitar, or vocals. The bassist and drummer are the heart beat of the band and those 2 must gel to make the band sound solid and tight.

Well I think many people are more captivated by the idea of playing guitar than the bass, and that accounts for the lower number of bassists. Amongst the few that play bass, many don’t feel very motivated to be good- they are often put in the background. The key is to find someone who has been playing for at least 3 years consistently, and is comfortable with the instrument and the idea of being a part of the rhythm, not the lead (no bassist should expect a lead role). The more you want your band and music to feature the bassist, the better they have to be. Don’t compromise for a crappy bassist, because that will give you a crappy sound.

Because by and large most people wanna be a guitar hero or a singer or whatever gets them the most attention. Us REAL bassists who started out on bass are few and far between. BTW, bass is NOT easy unless you wanna play simple AC/DC or Motley Crue bass lines. Listen to John Myung of Dream Theater or Getty Lee of Rush. Their playing is by no means easy or simple. It takes great physical strength and dexterity to play that way. I like to say that bass is easy to learn but hard to master.

Here’s what you do. Instead of looking for a bass player. Look for a decent guitar player who can also write and be a pivotal part of the band. Then one day ask him “Hey man, you ever play bass?” The best bass players I’ve worked with were ex-guitar players who fell into the roll of bass player, myself included. I ended up being a bass player for two different bands!! Started buying bass equipment and everything!! It was pretty fun actually. The really good straight up bass players already have paid gigs lined up around the corner. You can’t afford them.

I haven’t seen much in the answers that talk about the team of a drummer and a bassist (a few statements). A good drummer with a strong rhythmic feel and vibe is more likely to attract a good bass player. Working with a solid drummer is FUN. In the days before PA systems were really mature (meaning big and powerful wide ranging in frequency) and could carry a bass, a bassist used to have to haul around the full bass set of equipment. I used to cart around a Kustom head with two cabinets of twin 15s (remember those pleated babies?) and a Standel with twin 15s. I envied horn players.

James is pretty much on the money - I can only speak for myself. I always had people to jam with and bands wanted me. It made me a better player, especially when great players like Dave Kikoski pull you out of a practice room saying “Hey, I have a practice room, and I need a Bass Player.” It certainly is an interesting thing when you are asked to play weddings, parties, Bar Mitzvahs ( and Bat Mitzvahs), socials, dances, Rock gigs, Jazz gigs, Lounge gigs, etc…If you find a bass player that has a good rig and a car and can follow changes and play decent lines ( in tune!) you will be doing alright. Good Luck!

Probably because until the rock era, they were in the background so much. It is still that way, but with McCartney out front, maybe not so stigmatized. How many can you name off the top of your head besides him? I got stuck at seven, make that eight: Carol King, Bill Wyman, Chris Squire, Geddy Lee, Jaco Pastorius (iPad auto-correct made that Jack), John Paul Jones, John Entwistle and … Peter Tork (sorry for not immediately remembering the rest of you)—oh, and Stanley Clark and Larry Graham. A few RIPs could be stated here. Try seeking a singer (or backup singer) who can also play bass. That’s what you might ask them to do anyway.

Bass players need to click with the drummer. If that doesn’t happen then forget it. Most bassists are guitar players as well, which can create some issues, especially if they think they’re better than the guitarists in the band. Bass players usually prefer to stay in the background and scope the room for chicks, which makes for sloppy music. It’s a common trait and some women, go for the big instrument. Ha,ha. Bass players are territorial and like adding their own licks and runs to cover songs, that may not sit well with bar bands.

Because good bass players are scarce, just like good guitar players are scarce. There are lots of people who wish they were good, but they haven’t been willing to continually practice and learn and improve. Also, it seems most people would rather play guitar than bass; so some bass players are people who weren’t motivated to become good on guitar, and they gravitated to bass because simple bass lines are relatively easy to play, and it can be easier to get gigs as a bass player than as a guitar player because bass players are less numerous.

I think it also depends on what you want from the bass player. Do you want the guy to be just a rhythm player or to be a star? Lots of really talented technical players might avoid bass because it has become a function more than a musical instrument. The bass can do so much more than hold the bottom and be the glue. ANY instrument can do that. The bass has fallen into a sad state with a few exceptions, like Les Claypool and Flea, over the past 30 years.

Bass players are usually active as performers, the good ones are busy. For bass players, it’s a buyer’s market. It is easier for bass players to seek out compatible bands than it is for for bands to seek out compatible bass players.

Mainly because everyone wants to sing , play lead or drums. Who wants to keep everything in control, while the rest of the group are jumping around, having sparks fly out of their pickups, doing somersaults, and all the other things you can get away with on stage? Me, that’s who :-)
Many bass players are guitar players who aren’t good enough on guitar to get the job, so they switch. They are generally adequate on the bass, but rarely get really good at bass specific techniques.

I guess most musicians dont take this role seriously enough. When making ads or post on your social medias or anywhere else about it, you should demonstrate exactly what you are looking for and that you and your bandmates are serious about it, if you’re not doing that allready.
It's pretty easy for me since I'm the bass player. Also most people don't want to play bass because I actually have no idea bass is amazing.
I married mine so the revolving door of bass players would stop
That is surely because they are hiding behind a bigger instrument. A flutist, on the other hand is very easy to find. Even easier than the flute itself.
I have found too many want to play the complicated runs, but can’t hit the root on the beat to save their lives.
BOI!!!!!!!! Where were you a year ago. Thats how long I spent building a band. I Am The BASSIST.
